"Thank goodness you're awake, you gave us all a scare young man," the nurse said to the now awakened 'Ash', who was recovering from his dazed.

Later that evening, all Ash could do was stare in the mirror at his new body, now clad in a soft pink nightgown. He could barely believe this was his now; to all the world, he was Dawn. Even the real Dawn had been twisted into thinking he was really her. A part of him felt like this was wrong, but a larger part of him was far too fascinated to care. In truth, Ash had felt somewhat trapped before this, like he was stuck in a cycle of sorts. Maybe this was what he needed, to really be someone new. It was both frightening and exciting to him.

"Goodnight Dawn," he said to himself as he spun around, letting the dress and his hair twirl. "Tomorrow's a new day, in a lot of ways!"

*TWO WEEKS LATER*

Cheers rained from the crowd upon Ash as the announcer declared him winner of the Hearthome city contest. Clad in Dawn's contest dress, he curtsied to the audience. He took the ribbon and waved to the adulating crowd as he exited the stage, followed closely by Alakazam.

"Wouldn't have won that one if it weren't for you, Kazza. You're paying off in all kinds of ways!" Ash exclaimed once they found a more quiet hallway to finally relax in.

'You seem to be enjoying yourself quite a bit,' Alakazam replied. 'That body seems to suit you, don't you think?'

Ash gave a nervous smile as he undid Dawn's pontail, letting her hair fall past her shoulders. "Well, the contests definitely do. I never realized it was so fun having an audience! The gym's are challenging, but I sort of feel like I don't get much recognition out of them, y'know?"

Ash quieted suddenly as he heard the door creak open, bolting to attention as Brock entered the hallway.

"Hey Dawn! Just wanted to congratulate you! You did excellent out there," he exclaimed as he patted a hand on 'Dawn's' shoulder. "Were you talking to someone in here?"

"Oh! I was just on the phone," Ash lied. "And thanks! I really appreciate it. I think that accident a few weeks back has really given me some new energy, you know?"

"Yeah, I think I get what you mean," Brock replied, his tone suddenly becoming a bit more serious. "Listen, Dawn, I wanted to tell you something about Ash."

"What?" Ash replied, suddenly feeling a little bit worried.

"He's been acting just a bit... off, since the accident. He's been repeating a lot of the same phrases, acting really single-minded, and even seems to have forgotten a lot of stuff. I was reminiscing with him about a gym battle back in Hoenn the other night and he couldn't even remember the Gym leader's name. Barely remembered what happened! It's kind of worrying."

Ash glanced at Alakazam for a second, who had his eyes closed in thought. "Uh, wow Brock. That does sound worrying. Maybe the attack had more of an impact than we thought at first."

Brock nodded in reply. "I think so, which is why I decided to call his mother and Professor Oak. They agreed that I should take him back home to Kanto for a bit to recover. It's just not good for him to travel this way. I haven't told him yet; I wanted your help for that. What do you think?"

Ash was nervous now. He didn't think that Dawn's behavior was going to be a problem, but it seemed Brock was more observant than he gave him credit for. 'I guess I'm glad he cares.' "Uh, I guess you're right Brock. Let's wait until tomorrow though, okay?"

Brock nodded, "thanks for backing me up, Dawn. I'm going to go keep an eye on him until then, we'll be back at the center, okay?"

Brock departed, leaving Ash alone with Alakazam. "What do we now?" Ash asked, worried that the high from his joyride was about to come crashing into an end. "Do I really have to go back to normal?"

'Hmm, no, if you truly want to stay then there is one thing I can do.'

"What?" Ash asked, hopeful once more. He wanted to keep doing what he was doing; being new people and trying new things. He realized through being Dawn that he was just getting bored with the routine of his old life. He didn't want to go back to it yet.

'Dawn can't imitate you properly because her consciousness isn't using all of your brain. She's just imitating you using her own memories. I could use my power upon her while she sleeps and align her consciousness with your mind more thoroughly. She'd gain all of your memories and personality; no one would know the difference.'

"Just like that? No drawbacks?" Ash asked, for some reasoning doubting it'd be that easy.

Alakazam shook his head. 'It would be a very... invasive process. If I do it, there's no guarantee I can undo it. Not to mention, you agreed she should go to your hometown regardless. If I do it, you won't necessarily be stuck as Dawn, but you likely won't be able to be Ash anymore'

Ash was silent at this. Could he really do that? If he said yes, he'd basically be throwing away his own identity for good. He'd just be drifting from body to body. It was as frightening as it was exciting. He'd really be on an adventure that would never end. However, what would that mean for Dawn? In a way, it'd sort of be like killing her; basically a death of identity. He loved using her body, but he sort of went into this thinking he'd give it back to her at some point, if only because he wanted a different one. He could just have Alakazam switch the two of them back and hypnotize Dawn into a trade; that way he'd be able to take Alakazam back with him to Kanto and Dawn would get her life back. What did he do?

With an adult's body, you can gain the attention and recognition that your own body lacked, correct? You also have a level of authority that Dawn and you never had. No one would tell you where to go or what to do. Not to mention she has beauty and maturity.'
